docs.lead_paragraph: What determines how much we eat and how much we weigh? Is it the amount of fat in foods, the presence of carbohydrates, the size of our portions, what we drink with our meals, that elusive trait called willpower? Conflicting popular advice can prompt would-be dieters to give up before they even start. The good news based on solid research is that you can eat more -- probably more food than you're now eating -- and weigh less, if you choose more of the right kinds of foods.

headline.main: With Fruits and Vegetables, More Can Be Less

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses benefits of eating more fruits and vegetables as part of weight-loss plan; Dr Barbara J Rolls, Penn State University behavioral health professor and author of The Volumetrics Weight-Control Plan: Feel Full on Fewer Calories, describes concept of energy density and how it effects caloric intake; importance of water in diet discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: You can eat more  probably more food than you're now eating  and weigh less, if you choose more of the right kinds of foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kangaroo hunting and Coca-Cola don't mix -- at least when you drink more than two gallons of it while scouring the outback in the blazing heat. That was the conclusion of a case study published Saturday in The Lancet, a medical journal. It described an Australian ostrich farmer who was overcome by weakness after an evening of shooting kangaroos, which ''are considered agricultural pests'' in that region of the country, the study said.
docs.abstract: Lancet, medical journal, publishes case study of Australian man, who, after consuming large quantities of Coca-Cola, ended up in Princess Alexandra Hospital emergency room with severe potassium deficiency; sugar and caffeine promote fluid loss, which lowers potassium; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Kangaroo hunting and Coca-Cola don't mix  at least when you drink more than two gallons of it while scouring the outback in the blazing heat.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Strange Case of the Walking Corpse,'' by Nancy Butcher, Avery, $13.95. Medical cases can be depressing and inspiring, always educational -- and sometimes just plain weird. Ms. Butcher chronicles the latter, along with ''curious remedies, and bizarre but true healing folklore.''
docs.abstract: Nancy Butcher book The Strange Case of the Walking Corpse describes various medical oddities; photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''The Strange Case of the Walking Corpse,'' by Nancy Butcher, Avery, $13.95.      Medical cases can be depressing and inspiring, always educational -- and sometimes just plain weird. Ms. Butcher chronicles the latter, along with ''curious remedies,...

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: STRANGE CASE OF THE WALKING CORPSE, THE (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Smith could not breathe. Bright-red blood, filling up the air spaces in his lungs, was spewing from his mouth whenever he coughed. ''So what are you waiting for?'' I asked the cardiology fellow on the phone, trying to rub the sleep out of my eyes. ''Intubate him.''

headline.main: Give Up? No Way. On a Matter of Life or Death, a Patient Is Overruled.

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar Cases article describes post-surgical patient who did not want breathing tube inserted, but procedure was done against patient's wishes; without intubation patient would have died; medical ethics of situation discussed (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor takes a risk and goes against a patient's wishes in order to save his life.

docs.lead_paragraph: When 12-year-old Hannah Scott began middle school last year, she was so nervous that her stomach was not just in knots, it was in serious pain. ''It would start in the morning when I'd leave the house,'' said Hannah, a thin wisp of a girl with light brown freckles and long sandy hair. ''And when I got to school, it was really, really bad. I'd go to the nurse every other day, and be sent home.''

headline.main: How Doctors Help Children Tame the Beast in the Belly

docs.abstract: Estimated 10 to 20 percent of school-age children in US suffer severe recurrent abdominal pain, often diagnosed as irritable bowel syndrome; gastrointestinal specialists suggest that many doctors perform unnecessary tests and often do not know how to treat stomach pain in children; approaches like cognitive behavioral therapy, relaxation techniques and use of antidepressants are gaining ground, but have not been thoroughly tested for effectiveness; University of Pittsburgh study published in journal Pediatrics finds that 79 percent of children with recurrent abdominal pain have anxiety disorder; research on nerve cells and neurotransmitters in gastrointestinal tract is being conducted and supports apparent association between mind and stomach; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: An estimated 10 to 20 percent of all school-age children suffer severe recurrent abdominal pain, and many go months before being treated.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a baby's shoulder blocks passage into the birth canal, many obstetricians perform an episiotomy, in the belief that the incision, which widens the vagina, will lead to fewer fetal injuries. But according to a study released yesterday, episiotomies actually cause more injuries than they prevent.

headline.main: Clearing the Way for Baby, Safely

docs.abstract: Dr Edith D Gurewitsch, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine researcher, leads study that shows manual manipulation of fetus when shoulder dystocia occurs is safer on baby and mother than use of episiotomy to enlarge birth canal; only 35 percent of babies suffer arm injuries when obstetrician uses manual manipulation rather than 60 percent of babies with reported injuries when delivered using episiotomy (S)
docs.snippet: According to a new study, episiotomies actually cause more injuries than they prevent.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Merck Manual of Health & Aging, Merck Research Laboratories, Merck & Company Inc., $29.95. Ever since the first Merck Manual was published as a 192-page pocket-size medical reference in 1899 (the current version has 2,833 pages), it has been a much-thumbed fixture in doctors' offices, hospitals, laboratories and, in a lay version, packed with ample information for patients and hypochondriacs alike.
docs.abstract: Merck Research Laboratories publishes The Merck Manual of Health & Aging; book is divided into four sections on fundamentals of aging, caring for self and others, medical conditions and current issues on aging; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Reviews of a comprehensive guide "to the changes and challenges of aging" and a book that chronicles medicine's weirdest cases.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: MERCK MANUAL OF HEALTH & AGING, THE (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: A form of talk therapy was more effective than sleeping pills at reducing insomnia, and its effects were longer lasting, a new study has found. The study, published last week in The Archives of Internal Medicine, compared zolpidem tartrate, sold as Ambien, the most widely used sleeping pill, with cognitive behavior therapy.
docs.abstract: Dr Gregg D Jacobs of Harvard University Medical School leads study that suggests cognitive behavior therapy can help insomniacs sleep better and fall asleep faster; study is published in Archives of Internal Medicine; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A form of talk therapy was more effective than sleeping pills at reducing insomnia, and its effects were longer lasting, a new study has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: If nothing else, the removal of the painkiller Vioxx from the market last week served as a reminder that new drugs sometimes turn out to have unforeseen side effects after a few years of widespread use, and it makes sense to use them with caution. ''When we weigh the risks and benefits of medication, the word new has to be added to the risk side,'' said Dr. Susan Louisa Montauk, of the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine. ''That does not mean that one should never use a new drug, but it does make it a risk because major concerns can come up as long as 8 to 10 years down the line.''

headline.main: One Lesson From Vioxx: Approach New Drugs With Caution

docs.abstract: Removal of Vioxx from market after discovery that it increases risk of heart attack and stroke has reminded medical community to use caution in prescribing newer drugs; other cox-2 inhibitors taken by arthritic patients are currently being tested and it is unknown if they will be pulled from market as well; Dr Jerry Avorn, Harvard University medical professor and author of Power Medicines: The Benefits, Risks and Costs of Prescription Drugs blames aggressive marketing by drug companies as primary reason patients switched to newer drugs; holds older painkillers were quite effective except for those patients with intestinal sensitivity; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The removal of the painkiller from the market served as a reminder that new drugs sometimes turn out to have unforeseen side effects after a few years of widespread use.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Dead bodies after a natural disaster can start an epidemic. THE FACTS -- The hurricanes that swept through the Caribbean and the southeastern United States last month, claiming the lives of thousands of people, have revived a widespread health myth. After natural disasters that inflict enormous casualties, fears arise that dead bodies might set off an epidemic. Local health officials then bury remains without identifying them first, a drastic measure that only compounds grief for the victims' relatives. Experts say this happened after Hurricane Jeanne killed 2,000 people in Haiti last month and after major earthquakes shook Turkey in 2003 and El Salvador in 2001.
docs.abstract: Dead bodies left unburied after natural disaster do not pose substantial risk of causing epidemic; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The hurricanes that swept through the Caribbean and the southeastern United States lastmonth have revived a widespread health myth.
